newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia gold market decrees seen signed soon-agency.
newsitem.headline: Russia gold market decrees seen signed soon-agency.

text.p: Russian presidential decrees allowing the liberalisation of the gold market will be signed soon, Itar-Tass news agency quoted First Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly Chubais as saying on Tuesday.
Chubais also told the upper house of parliament Federation Council that to increase the government's control of the gold market would be "absurd."

"It is absurd that the state does not allow gold sales to anyone but itself, but can't afford to buy it itself. It is necessary to open the way for gold producers to enjoy realistic market demand," he said.
Chubais announced in April that the heavily-centralised gold market would be liberalised. A special working group was set up to look into concrete proposals for gold reforms.

One key element of the government's plan is to give producers greater freedom over who they sell their gold to. The working group, headed by Chubais, approved last month a resolution on direct gold sales to individuals.
It also recommended simplifying the procedure for exporting gold from Russia.
Commercial banks are also likely to be given a bigger role in any revamped gold market, above all in pre-financing output.

Gold output in 1997 is expected to be no more than 100 tonnes, Central Bank precious metals department head Sergei Kyshtymov said last week. This year's forecast was 11 to 12 percent below 1996 levels, he said. --Moscow Newsroom +7095 941 8520
